<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good morning. </strong>US financial markets are closed today to honor the life of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. And we are celebrating Dr. King’s legacy with a top story exploring the Federal Reserve’s recent shift to take a more active role in combating racial economic inequality. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Hope you have a reflective day.</p>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
INEQUALITY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/01/17/fed-tiptoes-race?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Fed Tiptoes Into Race
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Jerome Powell sitting at a desk looking concerned " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yMjMwL2plcm9tZV9wb3dlbGwuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Alex Wong/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">For the Federal Reserve, 2020 was a YOLO year. In response to the coronavirus crisis, the central bank quickly dropped interest rates to near-zero and, in unprecedented fashion, provided up to $2.3 trillion of financing to support businesses and markets. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It also confronted issues of racial inequality far more than it had since its founding in 1913. The killing of George Floyd last spring spurred calls for the Fed, the most powerful economic policymaking body in the world, to reflect on the ways its own actions have reinforced racial inequality—and use its influence to help address it.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The backstory </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Historically, the Fed has acted like a football player under Bill Belichick—it just tried to do its job. And that job, as mandated by Congress, is very clear: to 1) keep prices stable and 2) achieve maximum employment.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But by pursuing those goals like a horse with blinders, critics say, the Fed ignored racial economic inequality and perhaps <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/features/2021-federal-reserve-race-inequality/?srnd=premium&sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">made it worse</a>.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">One example: </strong></span><span>In the 1950s and 1970s, the Fed raised the cost of borrowing to slow down inflation growth (and fulfill job #1). According to Howard University economics professor Williams Spriggs, that tightening of credit disproportionately harmed Black Americans and inflated Black unemployment relative to the national average.   </span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The nowstory </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Fed is swapping its “do your job” approach in favor of a “with great power comes great responsibility” approach. In the fall, the Fed kicked off a series of events that explored the <a href="https://www.americanbanker.com/articles/fed-officials-vow-to-alter-long-held-practices-to-beat-inequity?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">central bank’s role</a> in racial economic inequality. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>First came the reckoning. The Fed “absolutely has to know, be passionate about, be interested in not just the wealthiest or the median, but all the people," said Ursula Burns, the former CEO of Xerox and the first Black female CEO of a Fortune 500 company.  </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Then came the pledge to do better. “We need to step forward and be present in this conversation and own that we have a role to play,” said Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic, the first Black person to lead a regional Fed bank.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Not everyone thinks the Fed should step outside its traditional job description. As Minneapolis Fed President Neel Kashkari pointed out, some people will say it’s Congress’s role, not the Fed’s, to tackle issues of racial inequality. The WSJ editorial board <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/a-peek-inside-a-biden-fed-11595286894?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">argued</a> a greater focus on race would lead to “ultraloose” monetary policy (inviting more inflation).</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead…</strong>the Fed’s greater attention to racial inequality is now being written into actual policies. Following a 20-month review, the Fed released new guidelines stating that maximum employment is a “broad-based and inclusive goal.” That’s central bank-speak for signaling it’ll consider the unemployment rate among minorities when making decisions.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ Optional homework: </strong>A Brew <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/29/diverse-federal-reserve?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">deep dive</a> into the diversity of the Fed’s leadership.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GOVERNMENT
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/01/17/biden-staff-reveals-plans-first-10-days?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Biden to Hit the Ground Executive Ordering
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Joe Biden" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNDEzL2pvZV9iaWRlbi5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em><a href="https://www.flickr.com/people/22007612@N05" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Gage Skidmore</a> from Surprise, AZ, United States of America, <a href="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Joe_Biden_(49554623208).jpg" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Joe Biden (49554623208)</a>, <a href="https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0/legalcode" class="link" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">CC BY-SA 2.0</a></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On Saturday, President-elect Joe Biden’s chief of staff, Ron Klain, <a href="https://www.axios.com/biden-oeverse-trump-policies-plan-inauguration-day-b902c149-677c-4070-8bf0-f06a5440ec4b.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">outlined</a> Biden’s plans for his first few days in office.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The primary theme: </strong>Donald who? The measures Biden plans to enact are <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/16/us/politics/biden-administration-executive-action-legislation.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">geared toward</a> undoing some of President Trump’s most controversial policies. That includes 1) scrapping the travel ban on majority-Muslim countries 2) rejoining the Paris Agreement and 3) establishing a path to citizenship for 11 million undocumented immigrants. Biden also plans to cancel the Keystone XL pipeline permit on his first day, CBC News <a href="https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/biden-keystone-xl-1.5877038?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">reported</a> yesterday.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The second theme</strong>: addressing the pandemic. To that end, Biden plans to 1) issue a mask mandate for all interstate travel and on federal property and 2) push for a meaty new round of stimulus. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Last week, he outlined plans for a $1.9 trillion stimulus bill. But remember, Congress controls the governmental purse strings, so Biden and his entourage will have to work with folks on Capitol Hill, including members of the opposing Republican Party. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>The average fingernail among Biden staffers probably isn’t in great shape. The administration <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/biden-day-one-agenda/2021/01/16/71540bde-576b-11eb-a931-5b162d0d033d_story.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">will take office</a> amid a triple threat of economic, public health, and social crises. </p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
AUTO
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/01/17/fiat-chrysler-psa-group-complete-merger-finally?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Paris and Milan Have That New Car Company Smell
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Stellantis logo" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zNzU3L3N0ZWxsYW50aXNfbG9nby5wbmciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Stellantis</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Fiat Chrysler and PSA Group, the maker of Peugeot and Citröen cars, <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-stellantis-deal/after-long-journey-fiat-chrysler-and-psa-seal-merger-to-become-stellantis-idUSKBN29L001?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">completed</a> their merger on Saturday, creating a brand new car company. The combo was <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/10/30/psa-psa-merge-fca?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">first announced</a> in October 2019, but Covid slowed down the i-dotting and t-crossing. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>It will begin trading in Milan and Paris today, and in New York tomorrow. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The new automaker’s name:</strong> Stellantis. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The game: </strong>combining the two legacy automakers’ resources to compete in a brave new electric world. Stellantis will be the world’s <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/fiat-chrysler-psa-group-merge-to-create-new-auto-making-behemoth-11610795486?mod=business_lead_pos1&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">third-largest automaker</a> by sales, per the latest available data, worth over $51 billion as of Friday’s close. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Current PSA CEO Carlos Tavares will attempt to steer the great ship Stellantis through squalls including underperforming factories, a sputtering Chinese presence, and overcapacity. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Stellantis enters the world with massive scale, which is key in the low-margin auto biz. But it will also need to invest billions to compete in the EV market, now a crowded field with both startups and legacy players hitting the accelerator. </p>

Twitter Banned Trump. Now What?

</h1>
</td>

</table>
<img alt="Locked phone" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xMTE4L2xvY2tlZF9waG9uZS5wbmciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Recent decisions by social media companies to ban or temporarily block President Trump’s accounts have sent Maui-size waves rippling across the world. Here’s the latest:</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How Twitter made the decision: </strong>Thanks to this <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/16/technology/inside-twitter-decision-trump.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">play-by-play</a> in the NYT, we know that CEO Jack Dorsey was on an island in French Polynesia “working remotely” (sure…) when he got a call from the company’s top lawyer and safety expert saying execs had decided to lock the president’s account following the attack on the Capitol. After initially hesitating, Dorsey later concluded that Trump crossed the line that meant a permanent suspension. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Less fake news? </strong>After social media sites suspended President Trump’s accounts, online misinformation about US election fraud <a href="https://www.businessinsider.com/misinformation-fell-73-after-trump-was-banned-across-social-media-2021-1?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">dropped</a> as much as 73% (from 2.5 million mentions to 688,000), according to research by analytics firm Zignal Labs. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Backlash: </strong>The decision by social media companies to simultaneously “deplatform” Trump has <a href="https://davidsacks.medium.com/the-speech-cartel-b3f5555f7787?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">raised questions</a> over their power to police online speech. Last week, leaders in Mexico and Poland said they’d favor <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2021/01/16/mexico-poland-social-media-trump/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">new regulations</a> that would ensure what happened to Trump can’t happen to them.</p>

CALENDAR
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/01/17/week-ahead-fortress-washington?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Week Ahead: “Fortress Washington”
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<img alt="Capitol Hill " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zNzU2L2NhcGl0b2xfaGlsbC5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">

</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Inauguration: </strong>On Wednesday, Joe Biden will be sworn in as the 46th US president. It’ll be a very different type of inauguration—the nation’s capital has effectively shut down in response to more threats of violence. Storefronts are boarded up and 25,000 National Guardsmen in total are arriving by Wednesday to secure the city. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>In lighter news, Lady Gaga, J.Lo, and Bruce Springsteen will </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/tom-hanks-lady-gaga-j-lo-and-others-will-entertain-at-joe-bidens-inauguration-11610757109?mod=hp_listc_pos4&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">perform</a></span><span> over the course of the day. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Earnings: </strong>This week’s slate features banks (Bank of America and Goldman Sachs), tech (Intel and IBM), and your favorite streaming giant (Netflix).</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Everything else:</strong></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Janet Yellen’s confirmation hearing for Treasury Secretary is set for Tuesday. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>A UN treaty banning nuclear weapons </span><span><a href="https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics/International-relations/UN-nuclear-ban-treaty-to-take-effect-on-Jan.-22?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">goes into effect</a></span><span> on Friday. However, the five permanent members of the UN Security Council (the US, Russia, Britain, China, and France) haven’t signed it.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Dolly Parton turns 75 tomorrow.</span></li>
</ul>

<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">

Winklevoss Twins: ‘Bitcoin Is Inevitable’
</font></a>
</h1>

<img alt="bitcoin bull" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zNzU1L2JpdGNvaW5fYnVsbC5wbmciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">You know bitcoin as the crypto that ate the internet in 2017 before...plummeting. But its latest rally, which rendezvoused above $40,000, shows it has more room to run.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">At least according to <strong style="color:#000">Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss</strong>, the billionaire twins behind crypto exchange Gemini and the spiciest scenes in <em>The Social Network</em>. Their prediction? Bitcoin to $500,000.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Today on <em>Business Casual, </em>the Winklevii explain their prediction and argue that widespread adoption of bitcoin will lift our economy out of its analog past and into a modern, digital future where inflation, wealth gaps, and currency constraints all shrink...at least in theory.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>They’d like widespread adoption to start with their new </span><span><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BCJ_dbJBIXc&feature=youtu.be&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Gemini crypto rewards credit card</a></span><span>. Because according to the Winklevii, bitcoin > airline miles just as much as Twitter > F*cebook.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">There’s so much more in the pod. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Listen now: </strong><a href="https://link.chtbl.com/winklevoss_apple?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Apple</a> / <a href="https://link.chtbl.com/winklevoss_spotify?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Spotify</a> / <a href="https://link.chtbl.com/winklevoss_all?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">everywhere else</a></p>
</td>

However, the new, highly contagious variants “\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/ScottGottliebMD/status/1350808526390767618?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emay change everything\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e,” per former FDA commissioner Scott Gottlieb. sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px\"\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding: 15px;\"\u003e\n\u003ch3 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nINEQUALITY \n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/01/17/fed-tiptoes-race?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nThe Fed Tiptoes Into Race\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Jerome Powell sitting at a desk looking concerned \" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yMjMwL2plcm9tZV9wb3dlbGwuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eAlex Wong/Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFor the Federal Reserve, 2020 was a YOLO year. In response to the coronavirus crisis, the central bank quickly dropped interest rates to near-zero and, in unprecedented fashion, provided up to $2.3 trillion of financing to support businesses and markets. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt also confronted issues of racial inequality far more than it had since its founding in 1913. The killing of George Floyd last spring spurred calls for the Fed, the most powerful economic policymaking body in the world, to reflect on the ways its own actions have reinforced racial inequality—and use its influence to help address it.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe backstory \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eHistorically, the Fed has acted like a football player under Bill Belichick—it just tried to do its job. And that job, as mandated by Congress, is very clear: to 1) keep prices stable and 2) achieve maximum employment.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut by pursuing those goals like a horse with blinders, critics say, the Fed ignored racial economic inequality and perhaps \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/features/2021-federal-reserve-race-inequality/?srnd=premium\u0026sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emade it worse\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eOne example: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIn the 1950s and 1970s, the Fed raised the cost of borrowing to slow down inflation growth (and fulfill job #1). According to Howard University economics professor Williams Spriggs, that tightening of credit disproportionately harmed Black Americans and inflated Black unemployment relative to the national average.   \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe nowstory \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe Fed is swapping its “do your job” approach in favor of a “with great power comes great responsibility” approach. In the fall, the Fed kicked off a series of events that explored the \u003ca href=\"https://www.americanbanker.com/articles/fed-officials-vow-to-alter-long-held-practices-to-beat-inequity?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecentral bank’s role\u003c/a\u003e in racial economic inequality. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eFirst came the reckoning. The Fed “absolutely has to know, be passionate about, be interested in not just the wealthiest or the median, but all the people,\" said Ursula Burns, the former CEO of Xerox and the first Black female CEO of a Fortune 500 company.  \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThen came the pledge to do better. “We need to step forward and be present in this conversation and own that we have a role to play,” said Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic, the first Black person to lead a regional Fed bank.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNot everyone thinks the Fed should step outside its traditional job description. As Minneapolis Fed President Neel Kashkari pointed out, some people will say it’s Congress’s role, not the Fed’s, to tackle issues of racial inequality. The WSJ editorial board \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/a-peek-inside-a-biden-fed-11595286894?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eargued\u003c/a\u003e a greater focus on race would lead to “ultraloose” monetary policy (inviting more inflation).\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead…\u003c/strong\u003ethe Fed’s greater attention to racial inequality is now being written into actual policies. Following a 20-month review, the Fed released new guidelines stating that maximum employment is a “broad-based and inclusive goal.” That’s central bank-speak for signaling it’ll consider the unemployment rate among minorities when making decisions.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e+ Optional homework: \u003c/strong\u003eA Brew \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/07/29/diverse-federal-reserve?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edeep dive\u003c/a\u003e into the diversity of the Fed’s leadership.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL href=\"https://www.flickr.com/people/22007612@N05\" class=\"link\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eGage Skidmore\u003c/a\u003e from Surprise, AZ, United border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOn Saturday, President-elect Joe Biden’s chief of staff, Ron Klain, \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/biden-oeverse-trump-policies-plan-inauguration-day-b902c149-677c-4070-8bf0-f06a5440ec4b.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eoutlined\u003c/a\u003e Biden’s plans for his first few days in office.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe primary theme: \u003c/strong\u003eDonald who? The measures Biden plans to enact are \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/16/us/politics/biden-administration-executive-action-legislation.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003egeared toward\u003c/a\u003e undoing some of President Trump’s most controversial policies. That includes 1) scrapping the travel ban on majority-Muslim countries 2) rejoining the Paris Agreement and 3) establishing a path to citizenship for 11 million undocumented immigrants. Biden also plans to cancel the Keystone XL pipeline permit on his first day, CBC News \u003ca href=\"https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/biden-keystone-xl-1.5877038?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereported\u003c/a\u003e yesterday.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe second theme\u003c/strong\u003e: addressing the pandemic. To that end, Biden plans to 1) issue a mask mandate for all interstate travel and on federal property and 2) push for a meaty new round of stimulus. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eLast week, he outlined plans for a $1.9 trillion stimulus bill. But remember, Congress controls the governmental purse strings, so Biden and his entourage will have to work with folks on Capitol Hill, including members of the opposing Republican Party. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eThe average fingernail among Biden staffers probably isn’t in great shape. width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFiat Chrysler and PSA Group, the maker of Peugeot and Citröen cars, \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-stellantis-deal/after-long-journey-fiat-chrysler-and-psa-seal-merger-to-become-stellantis-idUSKBN29L001?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecompleted\u003c/a\u003e their merger on Saturday, creating a brand new car company. The combo was \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2019/10/30/psa-psa-merge-fca?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efirst announced\u003c/a\u003e in October 2019, but Covid slowed down the i-dotting and t-crossing. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIt will begin trading in Milan and Paris today, and in New York tomorrow. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe new automaker’s name:\u003c/strong\u003e Stellantis. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe game: \u003c/strong\u003ecombining the two legacy automakers’ resources to compete in a brave new electric world. Stellantis will be the world’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/fiat-chrysler-psa-group-merge-to-create-new-auto-making-behemoth-11610795486?mod=business_lead_pos1\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ethird-largest automaker\u003c/a\u003e by sales, per the latest available data, worth over $51 billion as of Friday’s close. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eCurrent PSA CEO Carlos Tavares will attempt to steer the great ship Stellantis through squalls including underperforming factories, a sputtering Chinese presence, and overcapacity. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eStellantis enters the world with massive scale, which is key in the low-margin auto biz. But it will also need to invest billions to compete in the EV market, now a crowded field with both startups and legacy players hitting the accelerator. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS Now What?\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Locked phone\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xMTE4L2xvY2tlZF9waG9uZS5wbmciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eRecent decisions by social media companies to ban or temporarily block President Trump’s accounts have sent Maui-size waves rippling across the world. Here’s the latest:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHow Twitter made the decision: \u003c/strong\u003eThanks to this \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/16/technology/inside-twitter-decision-trump.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eplay-by-play\u003c/a\u003e in the NYT, we know that CEO Jack Dorsey was on an island in French Polynesia “working remotely” (sure…) when he got a call from the company’s top lawyer and safety expert saying execs had decided to lock the president’s account following the attack on the Capitol. After initially hesitating, Dorsey later concluded that Trump crossed the line that meant a permanent suspension. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLess fake news? \u003c/strong\u003eAfter social media sites suspended President Trump’s accounts, online misinformation about US election fraud \u003ca href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/misinformation-fell-73-after-trump-was-banned-across-social-media-2021-1?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edropped\u003c/a\u003e as much as 73% (from 2.5 million mentions to 688,000), according to research by analytics firm Zignal Labs. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBacklash: \u003c/strong\u003eThe decision by social media companies to simultaneously “deplatform” Trump has \u003ca href=\"https://davidsacks.medium.com/the-speech-cartel-b3f5555f7787?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eraised questions\u003c/a\u003e over their power to police online speech. Last week, leaders in Mexico and Poland said they’d favor \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2021/01/16/mexico-poland-social-media-trump/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enew regulations\u003c/a\u003e that would ensure what happened to Trump can’t happen to
